!!Simulation Results 
Comparison of the two-dimensional $q=8$ Clock Model and [[Potts Model]] with the [[Heisenberg Group]].

|centered|k
| !| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c.png]] |
| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c.png]] |
| !$ c_N$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<(\Delta H)^2\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_M^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_E^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_c.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
!!Files
*[[Download Data Files|Research\Data\Results2.rar]]







!!Simulation Results 
Comparison of the two-dimensional $q=8$ Clock Model and [[Potts Model]] with the [[Heisenberg Group]].

|centered|k
| !| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |h
| !$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c.png]] |
| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c.png]] |
| !$ c_N$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<(\Delta H)^2\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_M^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_E^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_c.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group. 

!!Files
*[[Download Data Files|Research\Data\Results2.rar]]







!!Simulation Results 
Comparison of the two-dimensional $q=8$ Clock Model and [[Potts Model]] with the [[Heisenberg Group]].

|centered|k
| !| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c.png]] |
| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c.png]] |
| !$ c_N$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c.png]] |
| !$ (\Delta H)^2$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_M^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_E^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_c.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group. 

!!Files
*[[Download Data Files|Research\Data\Results2.rar]]







!!Simulation Results

| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |

| !$ c_N$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c.png]] |
| !$ (\Delta H)^2$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_c.png]] |

*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

|centered|k
| !| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c_ln.png]] |
| !$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |

*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

|centered|k
| !| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c.png]] |
| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c.png]] |
| !$ c_N$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c.png]] |
| !$ (\Delta H)^2$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_M^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_E^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_c.png]] |

!!Log-Log Plots
|centered|k
| !$\quad$| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$C$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c_ln.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group. 

!!Files
*[[Download Data Files|Research\Data\Results2.rar]]







!!Simulation Results 
Comparison of the two-dimensional $q=8$ Clock Model and [[Potts Model]] with the [[Heisenberg Group]].

|centered|k

| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c.png]] |

| !$ (\Delta H)^2$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_M^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_E^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_c.png]] |

|centered|k
| !$\qquad$| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$C$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c_ln.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

|centered|k

| !$\log$<br>$ \chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |

*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

!!Log-Log Plots

|centered|k
| !$\qquad$| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$C$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c_ln.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |

!!Log-Log Plots

|centered|k
| !$\qquad$| !Heisenberg Group | !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$C$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_b_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c_ln.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.
*The [[Heisenberg Group]] appears to be unique from the [[clock model]] in its magnetic susceptibility in the quasi-liquid region of stability.  Since magnetic susceptibility can be shown to be the sum of correlation functions, as shown here ([[Ising Model]]), it follows that there is very strong correlation in the quasi-liquid region of the Heisenberg group.

|centered|k
| !$\qquad$| !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$C$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c_ln.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.

{{sectionTOC{}}}
!!Simulation Results 
Comparison of the two-dimensional $q=8$ [[Clock Model]] and [[Potts Model]].

|centered|k
| !|  !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c.png]] |
| !$\chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c.png]] |
| !$ \left<H\right>$ |  [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c.png]] |
| !$ c_N$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c.png]] |
| !$ (\Delta H)^2$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, V_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_M^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M4_c.png]] |
| !$ Q_E^{(4)}$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_a.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E4_c.png]] |

!!Log-Log Plots

|centered|k
| !$\qquad\qquad$| !Clock Model | !Potts Model |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<M\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, M_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \chi_M$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, X_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$ \left<H\right>$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, E_c_ln.png]] |
| !$\log$<br>$C$ | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_a_ln.png]] | [img[Research\Images\2d Heis, C_c_ln.png]] |

!!Notes
*The $4^{\rm th}$ order energy cumulant for the Potts model appears to have no negative points, but I am fairly certain (based on other simulation data) that these points would be found if the temperature grid were finer.
*The cumulants were plotted by expanding the expression $Q_x^{(4)} = \left<\left(x-\left< x\right>\right)^4\right> - 3\left<\left(x-\left<x\right>\right)^2\right>^2 \; = \; \bigl<x^4\bigr>-3\left<x^2\right>^2-4\bigl<x\bigr>\left<x^3\right>+12\bigl<x\bigr>^2\left<x^2\right>-6\bigl<x\bigr>^4$.

!!Files
*[[Download Data Files|Research\Data\Results2.rar]]
<<sectionTOC>>

<html><iframe src="graph3d\examples\example09_dot_cloud_colors.html" width="100%" height="640"  style="border: none;"></iframe></html>

//{{{
// Pretty sure this is incomplete and experimental
// TODO: Fix it or remove it.

(function($){

merge(config.macros,{
  mptwCollapse: {
    handler: function(place,macroName,params) {
      createTiddlyButton(place, params[0] == '+' ? '\u25AD' : '\u25AC', 'collapse/uncollapse', function(){
        $(story.findContainingTiddler(place)).toggleClass('collapsed');
      });
    }
  }
});

/* this doesn't work unless you have a modified ViewTempate */
config.shadowTiddlers["MptwCollapsePluginStyles"] = ""
  +".collapsed .uncollapsedView { display:none;       }"
  +".collapsedView              { display:none;       }"
  +".collapsed .collapsedView   { display:block;      }"
  +".tiddler.collapsed          { padding-bottom:1em; }"
  +".tiddler.collapsed .title   { font-size:100%;     }"
;

store.addNotification("MptwCollapsePluginStyles",refreshStyles);

})(jQuery);

//}}}
